		public async Task Comments_idsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, Answers_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "comments/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Deletes a comment.
		/// 
		/// Use an access_token with write_access to delete a comment.
		/// 
		/// In practice, this method will never return an object.
		/// 
		/// Comments_idDeletePostByFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndPreview comments/{id}/delete
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Comments_idDeletePostByFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndPreviewAsync(int id, string filter, string callback, string site, bool preview, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "comments/"+id+"/delete?filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site))+"&preview="+preview;
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Post, requestUri))
			{
			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Edit an existing comment.
		/// 
		/// Use an access_token with write_access to edit an existing comment.
		/// 
		/// This method return the created comment.
		/// 
		/// Comments_idEditPostByFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndBodyAndPreview comments/{id}/edit
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Comments_idEditPostByFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndBodyAndPreviewAsync(int id, string filter, string callback, string site, string body, bool preview, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "comments/"+id+"/edit?filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site))+"&body=" + (body==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(body))+"&preview="+preview;
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Post, requestUri))
			{
			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the various error codes that can be produced by the API.
		/// 
		/// This method is provided for discovery, documentation, and testing purposes, it is not expected many applications will consume it during normal operation.
		/// 
		/// For testing purposes, look into the /errors/{id} method which simulates errors given a code.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of errors.
		/// 
		/// ErrorsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallback errors
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task ErrorsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "errors?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// This method allows you to generate an error.
		/// 
		/// This method is only intended for use when testing an application or library. Unlike other methods in the API, its contract is not frozen, and new error codes may be added at any time.
		/// 
		/// This method results in an error, which will be expressed with a 400 HTTP status code and setting the error* properties on the wrapper object.
		/// 
		/// Errors_idGet errors/{id}
		/// </summary>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Errors_idGetAsync(int id, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "errors/"+id;
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a stream of events that have occurred on the site.
		/// 
		/// The API considers the following "events":
		/// - posting a question
		/// - posting an answer
		/// - posting a comment
		/// - editing a post
		/// - creating a user
		/// 
		/// 
		/// 
		/// 
		/// Events are only accessible for 15 minutes after they occurred, and by default only events in the last 5 minutes are returned. You can specify the age of the oldest event returned by setting the since parameter.
		/// 
		/// It is advised that developers batch events by ids and make as few subsequent requests to other methods as possible.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of events.
		/// 
		/// EventsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndSince events
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="since">Unix date.</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task EventsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndSinceAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, int since, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "events?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site))+"&since="+since;
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Creates a new filter given a list of includes, excludes, a base filter, and whether or not this filter should be "unsafe".
		/// 
		/// Filter "safety" is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		/// 
		/// If no base filter is specified, the default filter is assumed. When building a filter from scratch, the none built-in filter is useful.
		/// 
		/// When the size of the parameters being sent to this method grows to large, problems can occur. This method will accept POST requests to mitigate this.
		/// 
		/// It is not expected that many applications will call this method at runtime, filters should be pre-calculated and "baked in" in the common cases. Furthermore, there are a number of built-in filters which cover common use cases.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a single filter.
		/// 
		/// FiltersCreateGetBy_baseAndExcludeAndIncludeAnd_unsafe filters/create
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="exclude">String list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="include">String list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task FiltersCreateGetBy_baseAndExcludeAndIncludeAnd_unsafeAsync(string _base, string exclude, string include, bool _unsafe, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "filters/create?base=" + (_base==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(_base))+"&exclude=" + (exclude==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(exclude))+"&include=" + (include==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(include))+"&unsafe="+_unsafe;
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the fields included by the given filters, and the "safeness" of those filters.
		/// 
		/// It is not expected that this method will be consumed by many applications at runtime, it is provided to aid in debugging.
		/// 
		/// {filters} can contain up to 20 semicolon delimited filters. Filters are obtained via calls to /filters/create, or by using a built-in filter.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of filters.
		/// 
		/// Filters_filtersGet filters/{filters}
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filters">String list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Filters_filtersGetAsync(string filters, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "filters/"+ (filters==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filters));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a user's inbox.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of inbox items.
		/// 
		/// InboxGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallback inbox
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task InboxGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "inbox?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the unread items in a user's inbox.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of inbox items.
		/// 
		/// InboxUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSince inbox/unread
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="since">Unix date.</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task InboxUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSinceAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, int since, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "inbox/unread?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&since="+since;
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a collection of statistics about the site.
		/// 
		/// Data to facilitate per-site customization, discover related sites, and aggregate statistics is all returned by this method.
		/// 
		/// This data is cached very aggressively, by design. Query sparingly, ideally no more than once an hour.
		/// 
		/// This method returns an info object.
		/// 
		/// InfoGetBySite info
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task InfoGetBySiteAsync(string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "info?site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the user associated with the passed access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a user.
		/// 
		/// MeGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = reputation => number
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = name => string
		///sort = modified => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = reputation => number
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = name => string
		///sort = modified => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the answers owned by the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of answers.
		/// 
		/// MeAnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/answers
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeAnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/answers?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns all of a user's associated accounts, given an access_token for them.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of network users.
		/// 
		/// MeAssociatedGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallback me/associated
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeAssociatedGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/associated?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the badges earned by the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of badges.
		/// 
		/// MeBadgesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/badges
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = rank => string
		///sort = name => string
		///sort = type => string
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = rank => string
		///sort = name => string
		///sort = type => string
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.

		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.

		///none, which is empty

		///

		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. 		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeBadgesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, BadgesGetByInnameAndOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{

"" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? 			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the comments owned by the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of comments.
		/// 
		/// MeCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/comments
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion

		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields

		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, Answers_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/comments?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the comments owned by the user associated with the given access_token that are in reply to the user identified by {toId}.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of comments.
		/// 
		/// MeComments_toIdGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/comments/{toId}
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeComments_toIdGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int toId, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, Answers_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/comments/"+toId+"?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the questions favorites by the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// MeFavoritesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/favorites
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///sort = added => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///sort = added => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeFavoritesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeFavoritesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/favorites?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the user identified by access_token's inbox.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of inbox items.
		/// 
		/// MeInboxGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/inbox
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeInboxGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/inbox?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the unread items in the user identified by access_token's inbox.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of inbox items.
		/// 
		/// MeInboxUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndSince me/inbox/unread
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="since">Unix date.</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeInboxUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAndSinceAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, int since, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/inbox/unread?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site))+"&since="+since;
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the comments mentioning the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of comments.
		/// 
		/// MeMentionedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/mentioned
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///

		///

		///none, which is empty
