		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeMentionedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, Answers_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/mentioned?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a record of merges that have occurred involving a user identified by an access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method allows you to take now invalid account ids and find what account they've become, or take currently valid account ids and find which ids were equivalent in the past.
		/// 
		/// This is most useful when confirming that an account_id is in fact "new" to an application.
		/// 
		/// Account merges can happen for a wide range of reasons, applications should not make assumptions that merges have particular causes.
		/// 
		/// Note that accounts are managed at a network level, users on a site may be merged due to an account level merge but there is no guarantee that a merge has an effect on any particular site.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of account_merge.
		/// 
		/// MeMergesGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallback me/merges
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeMergesGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/merges?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a user's notifications, given an access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of notifications.
		/// 
		/// MeNotificationsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/notifications
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeNotificationsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/notifications?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a user's unread notifications, given an access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of notifications.
		/// 
		/// MeNotificationsUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/notifications/unread
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. 		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeNotificationsUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/notifications/unread?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the privileges the user identified by access_token has.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of privileges.
		/// 
		/// MePrivilegesGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/privileges
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MePrivilegesGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/privileges?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the questions owned by the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// MeQuestionsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/questions
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeQuestionsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/questions?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the questions that have active bounties offered by the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// MeQuestionsFeaturedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/questions/featured
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.

		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeQuestionsFeaturedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/questions/featured?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the questions owned by the user associated with the given access_token that have no answers.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// MeQuestionsNo_answersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/questions/no-answers
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeQuestionsNo_answersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/questions/no-answers?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the questions owned by the user associated with the given access_token that have no accepted answer.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// MeQuestionsUnacceptedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/questions/unaccepted
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeQuestionsUnacceptedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/questions/unaccepted?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the questions owned by the user associated with the given access_token that are not considered answered.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// MeQuestionsUnansweredGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/questions/unanswered
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeQuestionsUnansweredGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/questions/unanswered?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the reputation changed for the user associated with the given access_token.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of reputation changes.
		/// 
		/// MeReputationGetByFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/reputation
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeReputationGetByFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/reputation?filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns user's public reputation history.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of reputation_history.
		/// 
		/// MeReputation_historyGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/reputation-history
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. 		///
