		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeReputation_historyGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/reputation-history?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns user's full reputation history, including private events.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "private_info".
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of reputation_history.
		/// 
		/// MeReputation_historyFullGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/reputation-history/full
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeReputation_historyFullGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/reputation-history/full?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the suggested edits the user identified by access_token has submitted.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of suggested-edits.
		/// 
		/// MeSuggested_editsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/suggested-edits
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = approval => date
		///sort = rejection => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = approval => date
		///sort = rejection => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeSuggested_editsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeSuggested_editsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/suggested-edits?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the tags the user identified by the access_token passed is active in.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of tags.
		/// 
		/// MeTagsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/tags
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = popular => number
		///sort = activity => date
		///sort = name => string
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = popular => number
		///sort = activity => date
		///sort = name => string
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeTagsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeTagsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/tags?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the top 30 answers the user associated with the given access_token has posted in response to questions with the given tags.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of answers.
		/// 
		/// MeTags_tagsTop_answersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/tags/{tags}/top-answers
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="tags">String list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeTags_tagsTop_answersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string tags, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/tags/"+ (tags==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(tags))+"/top-answers&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the top 30 questions the user associated with the given access_token has posted in response to questions with the given tags.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// MeTags_tagsTop_questionsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/tags/{tags}/top-questions
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="tags">String list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///sort = hot => none
		///sort = week => none
		///sort = month => none
		///sort = relevance => none
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///sort = hot => none
		///sort = week => none
		///sort = month => none
		///sort = relevance => none
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeTags_tagsTop_questionsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string tags, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeTags_tagsTop_questionsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/tags/"+ (tags==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(tags))+"/top-questions&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a subset of the actions the user identified by the passed access_token has taken on the site.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of user timeline objects.
		/// 
		/// MeTimelineGetByFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/timeline
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeTimelineGetByFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/timeline?fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the user identified by access_token's top 30 tags by answer score.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of top tag objects.
		/// 
		/// MeTop_answer_tagsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/top-answer-tags
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeTop_answer_tagsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/top-answer-tags?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the user identified by access_token's top 30 tags by question score.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of top tag objects.
		/// 
		/// MeTop_question_tagsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/top-question-tags
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. 		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. 		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeTop_question_tagsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/top-question-tags?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the write permissions a user has via the api, given an access token.
		/// 
		/// The Stack Exchange API gives users the ability to create, edit, and delete certain types. This method returns whether the passed user is capable of performing those actions at all, as well as how many times a day they can.
		/// 
		/// This method does not consider the user's current quota (ie. if they've already exhausted it for today) nor any additional restrictions on write access, such as editing deleted comments.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of write_permissions.
		/// 
		/// MeWrite_permissionsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite me/write-permissions
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task MeWrite_permissionsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "me/write-permissions?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a user's notifications.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of notifications.
		/// 
		/// NotificationsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallback notifications
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task NotificationsGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "notifications?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a user's unread notifications.
		/// 
		/// This method requires an access_token, with a scope containing "read_inbox".
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of notifications.
		/// 
		/// NotificationsUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallback notifications/unread
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.

		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task NotificationsUnreadGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAsync(int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "notifications/unread?pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Fetches all posts (questions and answers) on the site.
		/// 
		/// In many ways this method is the union of /questions and /answers, returning both sets of data albeit only the common fields.
		/// 
		/// Most applications should use the question or answer specific methods, but /posts is available for those rare cases where any activity is of intereset. Examples of such queries would be: "all posts on Jan. 1st 2011" or "top 10 posts by score of all time".
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the post object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of posts.
		/// 
		/// PostsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite posts
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task PostsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "posts?order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Fetches a set of posts by ids.
		/// 
		/// This method is meant for grabbing an object when unsure whether an id identifies a question or an answer. This is most common with user entered data.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for post_id, answer_id, or question_id on post, answer, and question objects respectively.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the post object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of posts.
		/// 
		/// Posts_idsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite posts/{ids}
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Posts_idsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "posts/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets the comments on the posts identified in ids, regardless of the type of the posts.
		/// 
		/// This method is meant for cases when you are unsure of the type of the post id provided. Generally, this would be due to obtaining the post id directly from a user.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for post_id, answer_id, or question_id on post, answer, and question objects respectively.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the comment object:
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// creation is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of comments.
		/// 
		/// Posts_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite posts/{ids}/comments
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Posts_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, Answers_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "posts/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/comments&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns edit revisions for the posts identified in ids.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for post_id, answer_id, or question_id on post, answer, and question objects respectively.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of revisions.
		/// 
		/// Posts_idsRevisionsGetByFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite posts/{ids}/revisions
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
