"" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Get the comments that the users in {ids} have posted in reply to the single user identified in {toid}.
		/// 
		/// This method is useful for extracting conversations, especially over time or across multiple posts.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects. {toid} can contain only 1 id, found in the same manner as those in {ids}.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the comment object:
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// creation is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of comments.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsComments_toidGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/comments/{toid}
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsComments_toidGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, int toid, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, Answers_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/comments/"+toid+"&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Get the questions that users in {ids} have favorited.
		/// 
		/// This method is effectively a view onto a user's favorites tab.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the question object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// - added - when the user favorited the question
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsFavoritesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/favorites
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///sort = added => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///sort = added => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsFavoritesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeFavoritesGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/favorites&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets all the comments that the users in {ids} were mentioned in.
		/// 
		/// Note, to count as a mention the comment must be considered to be "in reply to" a user. Most importantly, this means that a comment can only be in reply to a single user.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the comment object:
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of comments.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsMentionedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/mentioned
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsMentionedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, Answers_idsCommentsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/mentioned&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns a record of merges that have occurred involving the passed account ids.
		/// 
		/// This method allows you to take now invalid account ids and find what account they've become, or take currently valid account ids and find which ids were equivalent in the past.
		/// 
		/// This is most useful when confirming that an account_id is in fact "new" to an application.
		/// 
		/// Account merges can happen for a wide range of reasons, applications should not make assumptions that merges have particular causes.
		/// 
		/// Note that accounts are managed at a network level, users on a site may be merged due to an account level merge but there is no guarantee that a merge has an effect on any particular site.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of account_merge.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsMergesGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallback users/{ids}/merges
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsMergesGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAsync(string ids, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/merges&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets the questions asked by the users in {ids}.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the question object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsQuestionsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/questions
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsQuestionsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/questions&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets the questions on which the users in {ids} have active bounties.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the question object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsQuestionsFeaturedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/questions/featured
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsQuestionsFeaturedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/questions/featured&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets the questions asked by the users in {ids} which have no answers.
		/// 
		/// Questions returns by this method actually have zero undeleted answers. It is completely disjoint /users/{ids}/questions/unanswered and /users/{ids}/questions/unaccepted, which only return questions with at least one answer, subject to other contraints.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the question object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsQuestionsNo_answersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/questions/no-answers
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsQuestionsNo_answersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/questions/no-answers&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets the questions asked by the users in {ids} which have at least one answer, but no accepted answer.
		/// 
		/// Questions returned by this method have answers, but the owner has not opted to accept any of them.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the question object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsQuestionsUnacceptedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/questions/unaccepted
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsQuestionsUnacceptedGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/questions/unaccepted&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets the questions asked by the users in {ids} which the site consideres unanswered, while still having at least one answer posted.
		/// 
		/// These rules are subject to change, but currently any question without at least one upvoted or accepted answer is considered unanswered.
		/// 
		/// To get the set of questions that a user probably considers unanswered, the returned questions should be unioned with those returned by /users/{id}/questions/no-answers. These methods are distinct so that truly unanswered (that is, zero posted answers) questions can be easily separated from mearly poorly or inadequately answered ones.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the question object:
		/// - activity - last_activity_date
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - votes - score
		/// activity is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of questions.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsQuestionsUnansweredGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/questions/unanswered
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = activity => date
		///sort = creation => date
		///sort = votes => number
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsQuestionsUnansweredGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/questions/unanswered&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Gets a subset of the reputation changes for users in {ids}.
		/// 
		/// Reputation changes are intentionally scrubbed of some data to make it difficult to correlate votes on particular posts with user reputation changes. That being said, this method returns enough data for reasonable display of reputation trends.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of reputation objects.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsReputationGetByFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/reputation
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsReputationGetByFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/reputation&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns users' public reputation history.
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of reputation_history.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsReputation_historyGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/reputation-history
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsReputation_historyGetByPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/reputation-history&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the suggested edits a users in {ids} have submitted.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the suggested_edit object:
		/// - creation - creation_date
		/// - approval - approval_date Does not return unapproved suggested_edits
		/// - rejection - rejection_date Does not return unrejected suggested_edits
		/// creation is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of suggested-edits.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsSuggested_editsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/suggested-edits
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = creation => date
		///sort = approval => date
		///sort = rejection => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = creation => date
		///sort = approval => date
		///sort = rejection => date
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsSuggested_editsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeSuggested_editsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
			var requestUri = "users/"+ (ids==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(ids))+"/suggested-edits&order=" + order+"&max=" + (max==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(max))+"&min=" + (min==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(min))+"&sort=" + sort+"&fromdate="+fromdate+"&todate="+todate+"&pagesize="+pagesize+"&page="+page+"&filter=" + (filter==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(filter))+"&callback=" + (callback==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(callback))+"&site=" + (site==null? "" : System.Uri.EscapeDataString(site));
			using (var httpRequestMessage = new System.Net.Http.HttpRequestMessage(System.Net.Http.HttpMethod.Get, requestUri))
			{
			if (handleHeaders != null)
			{
				handleHeaders(httpRequestMessage.Headers);
			}

			var responseMessage = await httpClient.SendAsync(httpRequestMessage);
			try
			{
				responseMessage.EnsureSuccessStatusCodeEx();
			}
			finally
			{
				responseMessage.Dispose();
			}
			}
		}
		
		/// <summary>
		/// Returns the tags the users identified in {ids} have been active in.
		/// 
		/// This route corresponds roughly to user's stats tab, but does not include tag scores. A subset of tag scores are available (on a single user basis) in /users/{id}/top-answer-tags and /users/{id}/top-question-tags.
		/// 
		/// {ids} can contain up to 100 semicolon delimited ids, to find ids programatically look for user_id on user or shallow_user objects.
		/// 
		/// The sorts accepted by this method operate on the follow fields of the tag object:
		/// - popular - count
		/// - activity - the creation_date of the last question asked with the tag
		/// - name - name
		/// popular is the default sort.
		/// 
		/// It is possible to create moderately complex queries using sort, min, max, fromdate, and todate.
		/// 
		/// 
		/// This method returns a list of tags.
		/// 
		/// Users_idsTagsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSite users/{ids}/tags
		/// </summary>
		/// <param name="ids">Number list (semicolon delimited).</param>
		/// <param name="max">sort = popular => number
		///sort = activity => date
		///sort = name => string
		///</param>
		/// <param name="min">sort = popular => number
		///sort = activity => date
		///sort = name => string
		///</param>
		/// <param name="fromdate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="todate">Unix date.</param>
		/// <param name="filter">#Discussion
		///
		///The Stack Exchange API allows applications to exclude almost every field returned. For example, if an application did not care about a user's badge counts it could exclude user.badge_counts whenever it calls a method that returns users.
		///
		///An application excludes fields by creating a filter (via /filter/create) and passing it to a method in the filter parameter.
		///
		///Filters are immutable and non-expiring. An application can safely "bake in" any filters that are created, it is not necessary (or advisable) to create filters at runtime.
		///
		///The motivation for filters are several fold. Filters allow applications to reduce API responses to just the fields they are concerned with, saving bandwidth. With the list of fields an application is actually concerned with, the API can avoid unneccessary queries thereby decreasing response time (and reducing load on our infrastructure). Finally, filters allow us to be more conservative in what the API returns by default without a proliferation of parameters (as was seen with body, answers, and comments in the 1.x API family).
		///
		///#Safety
		///
		///Filters also carry a notion of safety, which is defined as follows. Any string returned as a result of an API call with a safe filter will be inline-able into HTML without script-injection concerns. That is to say, no additional sanitizing (encoding, HTML tag stripping, etc.) will be necessary on returned strings. Applications that wish to handle sanitizing themselves should create an unsafe filter. All filters are safe by default, under the assumption that double-encoding bugs are more desirable than script injections.
		///
		///Note that this does not mean that "safe" filter is mearly an "unsafe" one with all fields passed though UrlEncode(...). Many fields can and will contain HTML in all filter types (most notably, the *.body fields).
		///
		///When using unsafe filters, the API returns the highest fidelity data it can reasonably access for the given request. This means that in cases where the "safe" data is the only accessible data it will be returned even in "unsafe" filters. Notably the *.body fields are unchanged, as they are stored in that form. Fields that are unchanged between safe and unsafe filters are denoted in their types documentation.
		///
		///#Built In Filters
		///
		///The following filters are built in:
		///
		///default, each type documents which fields are returned under the default filter (for example, answers).
		///withbody, which is default plus the *.body fields
		///none, which is empty
		///total, which includes just .total
		///
		///#Compatibility with V1.x
		///
		///For ease of transition from earlier API versions, the filters _b, _ba, _bc, _bca, _a, _ac, and _c are also built in. These are unsafe, and exclude a combination of question and answer body, comments, and answers so as to mimic the body, answers, and comments parameters that have been removed in V2.0. New applications should not use these filters.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="callback">All API responses are JSON, we do support JSONP with the callback query parameter.
		///</param>
		/// <param name="site">Each of these methods operates on a single site at a time, identified by the site parameter. This parameter can be the full domain name (ie. "stackoverflow.com"), or a short form identified by api_site_parameter on the site object.
		///</param>
		/// <returns>OK</returns>
		public async Task Users_idsTagsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteAsync(string ids, AnswersGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteOrder order, string max, string min, MeTagsGetByOrderAndMaxAndMinAndSortAndFromdateAndTodateAndPagesizeAndPageAndFilterAndCallbackAndSiteSort sort, int fromdate, int todate, int pagesize, int page, string filter, string callback, string site, Action<System.Net.Http.Headers.HttpRequestHeaders> handleHeaders = null)
		{
